title-group.article-title: On the Condition of a Matrix Arising in the Numerical Inversion of the Laplace Transform

abstract.p: Bellman, Kalaba, and Lockett recently proposed a numerical method for inverting the Laplace transform. The method consists in first reducing the infinite interval of integration to a finite one by a preliminary substitution of variables, and then employing an n-point Gauss-Legendre quadrature formula to reduce the inversion problem (approximately) to that of solving a system of n linear algebraic equations. Luke suggests the possibility of using Gauss-Jacobi quadrature (with parameters |alpha and β) in place of Gauss-Legendre quadrature, and in particular raises the question whether a judicious choice of the parameters α, β may have a beneficial influence on the condition of the linear system of equations. The object of this note is to investigate the condition number <tex-math>$\operatorname{cond} (n, \alpha, \beta)$</tex-math> of this system as a function of n, α, and β. It is found that <tex-math>$\operatorname{cond} (n, \alpha, \beta)$</tex-math> is usually larger than <tex-math>$\operatorname{cond} (n, \beta, \alpha)$</tex-math> if <latex>$\beta > \alpha$</latex>, at least asymptotically as n → ∞. Lower bounds for <tex-math>$\operatorname{cond} (n, \alpha, \beta)$</tex-math> are obtained together with their asymptotic behavior as n → ∞. Sharper bounds are derived in the special cases α = β, n odd, and α = β = ± 1/2, n arbitrary. There is also a short table of <tex-math>$\operatorname{cond} (n, \alpha, \beta)$</tex-math> for α, β = -.8(.2)0, .5, 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, β ≤ α, and n = 5, 10, 20, 40. The general conclusion is that <tex-math>$\operatorname{cond} (n, \alpha, \beta)$</tex-math> grows at a rate which is something like a constant times (3 + √ 8)<sup>n</sup>, where the constant depends on α and β, varies relatively slowly as a function of α, β, and appears to be smallest near α = β = -1. For quadrature rules with equidistant points the condition grows like (2 √ 2/3π)8<sup>n</sup>.
